must take place at regular and equal intervals from the point 
of contact or vertex of the angle; corresponding to the 
natural numbers of which the measurements of the rings 
expresses the square roots; that is as the series 0, 2, 4, 6, 
8, &c. the principle is therefore fully confirmed by this 
experiment. 
12 Ex. <s>20<\s>. Those primary fringes have also transmitted sets 
between them, alternate in colours to their primaries, exactly 
similar to Newtonian rings; for by placeing them long-
itudinally in the direction of the light, & by using the 
shadow of a black card thrown across them, both primaries 
& transmitted fringes may be seen at once by the naked 
eye. Let the light come in the direction AB in fig. 5 <s>7<\s> & 
let CD represent the edge of the shadow next the light 
those fringes above the line CD are primaries, & those 
below it are transmitted sets, alternate in colours to the 
others. altho these primary fringes are uniform in their 
breadths, they are not quite so with respect to colour; 
for the yellow, blue, indigo & violet, are predominant 
in the 1st, 2d, & 3d fringes next to the place of contact; 
altho' these 4 colours are but little perceived after the 3d 
fringe, where 10 are seen; the red orange & green 
being predominant in all the rest. 
13 Ex. <s>21<\s>. After having produced one set of primary fringes 
I succeeded in having another set formed at right angles 
therto, by applying a 3d slip of glass longitudinally to the 
upper one of the first two, on which the expected diagonal 
fringes immediately appeared in the angle between the 
two primary sets, as showen in fig. <s>8<\s>. where B & C are 
the primary fringes & D the intersectionary set divided 
into two classes, as showen by the dotted line.
